snippet: Another baby born with H.I.V. and treated with drugs shortly after birth is now 9 months old and apparently H.I.V.-negative. The success of the treatment raises hopes for a path to rid babies of the virus that causes AIDS.
abstract: Researchers at the Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections reveal that a second baby has been apparently cured of HIV through aggressive drug treatment shortly after birth, leaving little doubt that treatment works; add that, if successful, clinical trial set to begin could remake protocol for treating all 250,000 babies born infected each year worldwide; announcement is latest hopeful news about virus that causes AIDS.
lead_paragraph: Another baby born with H.I.V. and treated with drugs shortly after birth is now 9 months old and apparently H.I.V.-negative. The success of the treatment raises hopes for a path to rid babies of the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: Early Treatment Is Found to Clear H.I.V. in a 2nd Baby
headline.print_headline: Early Treatment Found to Clear H.I.V. in 2nd Baby
